Clustered Federated Learning: Model-Agnostic Distributed Multi-Task Optimization under Privacy Constraints

Felix Sattler, Klaus-Robert M√ºller*,¬†, and Wojciech Samek This work was supported by the German Ministry for Education and Research as Berlin Big Data Center (01IS14013A) and the Berlin Center for Machine Learning (01IS18037I). Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is currently the most widely adopted framework for collaborative training of (deep) machine learning models under privacy constraints. Albeit it‚Äôs popularity, it has been observed that Federated Learning yields suboptimal results if the local clients‚Äô data distributions diverge. To address this issue, we present Clustered Federated Learning (CFL), a novel Federated Multi-Task Learning (FMTL) framework, which exploits geometric properties of the FL loss surface, to group the client population into clusters with jointly trainable data distributions. In contrast to existing FMTL approaches, CFL does not require any modifications to the FL communication protocol to be made, is applicable to general non-convex objectives (in particular deep neural networks) and comes with strong mathematical guarantees on the clustering quality. CFL is flexible enough to handle client populations that vary over time and can be implemented in a privacy preserving way. As clustering is only performed after Federated Learning has converged to a stationary point, CFL can be viewed as a post-processing method that will always achieve greater or equal performance than conventional FL by allowing clients to arrive at more specialized models. We verify our theoretical analysis in experiments with deep convolutional and recurrent neural networks on commonly used Federated Learning datasets.

I Introduction

Federated Learning [1][2][3][4][5] is a distributed training framework, which allows multiple clients (typically mobile or IoT devices) to jointly train a single deep learning model on their combined data in a communication-efficient way, without requiring any of the participants to reveal their private training data to a centralized entity or to each other. Federated Learning realizes this goal via an iterative three-step protocol where in every communication round tùë°t, the clients first synchronize with the server by downloading the latest master model Œ∏tsubscriptùúÉùë°\theta_{t}. Every client then proceeds to improve the downloaded model, by performing multiple iterations of stochastic gradient descent with mini-batches sampled from it‚Äôs local data Disubscriptùê∑ùëñD_{i}, resulting in a weight-update vector

ŒîŒ∏it+1=SGDk(Œ∏t,Di)‚àíŒ∏t,i=1,..,m\displaystyle\Delta\theta_{i}^{t+1}=\text{SGD}_{k}(\theta^{t},D_{i})-\theta^{t},\leavevmode\nobreak\ i=1,..,m (1)

Finally, all clients upload their computed weight-updates to the server, where they are aggregated by weighted averaging according to

Œ∏t+1=Œ∏t+‚àëi=1m|Di||D|‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏it+1superscriptùúÉùë°1superscriptùúÉùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscriptùê∑ùëñùê∑ŒîsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùë°1\displaystyle\theta^{t+1}=\theta^{t}+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{|D_{i}|}{|D|}\Delta\theta_{i}^{t+1} (2)

to create the next master model. The procedure is summarized in Algorithm 2.

Federated Learning implicitly makes the assumption that it is possible for one single model to fit all client‚Äôs data generating distributions œÜisubscriptùúëùëñ\varphi_{i} at the same time. Given a model fŒ∏:ùí≥‚Üíùí¥:subscriptùëìùúÉ‚Üíùí≥ùí¥f_{\theta}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} parametrized by Œ∏‚ààŒòùúÉŒò\theta\in\Theta and a loss function l:ùí¥√óùí¥‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùëô‚Üíùí¥ùí¥subscript‚Ñùabsent0l:\mathcal{Y}\times\mathcal{Y}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} we can formally state this assumption as follows:

Assumption 1.

("Federated Learning"): There exists a parameter configuration Œ∏‚àó‚ààŒòsuperscriptŒ∏Œò\theta^{*}\in\Theta, that (locally) minimizes the risk on all clients‚Äô data generating distributions at the same time:

Ri(Œ∏‚àó)‚â§Ri(Œ∏)‚àÄŒ∏‚ààBŒµ(Œ∏‚àó),i=1,..,m\displaystyle R_{i}(\theta^{*})\leq R_{i}(\theta)\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall\theta\in B_{\varepsilon}(\theta^{*}),i=1,..,m (3)

for some Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0. Hereby

Ri‚Äã(Œ∏)=‚à´l‚Äã(fŒ∏‚Äã(x),y)‚ÄãùëëœÜi‚Äã(x,y)subscriptùëÖùëñùúÉùëôsubscriptùëìùúÉùë•ùë¶differential-dsubscriptùúëùëñùë•ùë¶\displaystyle R_{i}(\theta)=\int l(f_{\theta}(x),y)d\varphi_{i}(x,y) (4)

is the risk function associated with distribution œÜisubscriptùúëùëñ\varphi_{i}.

It is easy to see that this assumption is not always satisfied. Concretely it is violated if either (a) clients have disagreeing conditional distributions œÜi‚Äã(y|x)‚â†œÜj‚Äã(y|x)subscriptùúëùëñconditionalùë¶ùë•subscriptùúëùëóconditionalùë¶ùë•\varphi_{i}(y|x)\neq\varphi_{j}(y|x) or (b) the model fŒ∏subscriptùëìùúÉf_{\theta} is not expressive enough to fit all distributions at the same time. Simple counter examples for both cases are presented in Figure 1.

In the following we will call a set of clients and their data generating distributions œÜùúë\varphi congruent (with respect to fùëìf and lùëôl) if they satisfy Assumption 1 and incongruent if they don‚Äôt.

In this work, we argue that Assumption 1 is frequently violated in real Federated Learning applications, especially given the fact that in Federated Learning clients (a) can hold arbitrary non-iid data, which can not be audited by the centralized server due to privacy constraints and (b) typically run on limited hardware which puts restrictions on the model complexity. For illustration consider the following practical scenarios:

Varying Preferences: Assume a scenario where every client holds a local dataset of images of human faces and the goal is to train an ‚Äôattractiveness‚Äô classifier on the joint data of all clients. Naturally, different clients will have varying opinions about the attractiveness of certain individuals, which corresponds to disagreeing conditional distributions on all clients‚Äô data. Assume for instance that one half of the client population thinks that people wearing glasses are attractive, while the other half thinks that those people are unattractive. In this situation one single model will never be able to accurately predict attractiveness of glasses-wearing people for all clients at the same time (confer also Figure 1 right).

Limited Model Complexity: Assume a number of clients are trying to jointly train a language model for next-word prediction on private text messages. In this scenario the statistics of a client‚Äôs text messages will likely vary a lot based on demographic factors, interests, etc. For instance, text messages composed by teenagers will typically exhibit different statistics than than those composed by elderly people. An insufficiently expressive model will not be able to fit the data of all clients at the same time.

Presence of Adversaries: A special case of incongruence is given, if a subset of the client population behaves in an adversarial manner. In this scenario the adversaries could deliberately alter their local data distribution in order to encode arbitrary behavior into the jointly trained model, thus affecting the model decisions on all other clients and causing potential harm.

The goal in Federated Multi-Task Learning is to provide every client with a model that optimally fits it‚Äôs local data distribution. In all of the above described situations the ordinary Federated Learning framework, in which all clients are treated equally and only one single global model is learned, is not capable of achieving this goal.

In order to incorporate the above presented problems with incongruent data generating distributions, we suggest to generalize the conventional Federated Learning Assumption:

Assumption 2.

("Clustered Federated Learning"): There exists a partitioning ùíû={c1,..,ck}\mathcal{C}=\{c_{1},..,c_{k}\}, ‚ãÉi=1kck={1,..,m}\bigcup_{i=1}^{k}c_{k}=\{1,..,m\} of the client population, such that every subset of clients c‚ààùíûcùíûc\in\mathcal{C} satisfies the conventional Federated Learning Assumption.

The remainder of this manuscript is organized as follows: In the next section (II) we will derive a computationally efficient tool based on the cosine similarity between the clients‚Äô gradient updates that provably allows us to infer whether two members of the client population have the same data generating distribution, thus making it possible for us to infer the clustering structure ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}. Based on the theoretical insights in section II we present the Clustered Federated Learning Algorithm in section III. After reviewing related literature in section IV, we address implementation details in section V and demonstrate that our novel method can be implemented without making modifications to the Federated Learning communication protocol (section V-A). We furthermore show that our method can be implemented in a privacy preserving way (section V-B) and is flexible enough to handle client populations that vary over time (section V-C). Finally, in section VI, we perform extensive experiments on a variety of convolutional and recurrent neural networks applied to common Federated Learning datasets.

II Cosine Similarity based Clustering

In this paper, we address the question of how to solve distributed learning problems that satisfy Assumption 2 (which generalizes the Federated Learning Assumption 1). This will require us to first identify the correct partitioning ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, which at first glance seems like a daunting task, as under the Federated Learning paradigm the server has no access to the clients‚Äô data, their data generating distributions or any meta information thereof.

An easier task than trying to directly infer the entire clustering structure ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, is to find a correct bi-partitioning in the sense of the following definition:

Definition 1.

Let m‚â•k‚â•2ùëöùëò2m\geq k\geq 2 and

I:{1,..,m}‚Üí{1,..,k},i‚Ü¶I(i)\displaystyle I:\{1,..,m\}\rightarrow\{1,..,k\},i\mapsto I(i) (5)

be the mapping that assigns a client iùëñi to it‚Äôs data generating distribution œÜI‚Äã(i)subscriptùúëùêºùëñ\varphi_{I(i)}. Then we call a bi-partitioning c1‚à™Àôc2={1,..,m}c_{1}\dot{\cup}c_{2}=\{1,..,m\} with c1‚â†‚àÖsubscriptùëê1c_{1}\neq\emptyset and c2‚â†‚àÖsubscriptùëê2c_{2}\neq\emptyset correct if and only if

I‚Äã(i)‚â†I‚Äã(j)‚àÄi‚ààc1,j‚ààc2.formulae-sequenceùêºùëñùêºùëóformulae-sequencefor-allùëñsubscriptùëê1ùëósubscriptùëê2\displaystyle I(i)\neq I(j)\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}. (6)

In other words, a bi-partitioning is called correct, if clients with the same data generating distribution end up in the same cluster. It is easy to see, that the clustering ùíû={c1,..,ck}\mathcal{C}=\{c_{1},..,c_{k}\} can be obtained after exactly k‚àí1ùëò1k-1 correct bi-partitions.

In the following we will demonstrate that there exists an explicit criterion based on which a correct bi-partitioning can be inferred. To see this, let us first look at the following simplified Federated Learning setting with mùëöm clients, in which the data on every client was sampled from one of two data generating distributions œÜ1subscriptùúë1\varphi_{1}, œÜ2subscriptùúë2\varphi_{2} such that

II-A Distinguishing Congruent and Incongruent Clients

In order to appropriately generalize the classical Federated Learning setting, we need to make sure to only split up clients with incongruent data distributions. In the classical congruent non-iid Federated Learning setting described in [1] where one single model can be learned, performance will typically degrade if clients with varying distributions are separated into different clusters due to the restricted knowledge transfer between clients in different clusters. Luckily we have a criterion at hand to distinguish the two cases. To realize this we have inspect the gradients computed by the clients at a stationary point Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*}. When client distributions are incongruent, the stationary solution of the Federated Learning objective by definition can not be stationary for the individual clients. Hence the norm of the clients‚Äô gradients has to be strictly greater than zero. If conversely the client distributions are congruent, Federated optimization will be able to jointly optimize all clients‚Äô local risk functions and hence the norm of the clients‚Äô gradients will tend towards zero as we are approaching the stationary point. Based on this observation we can formulate the following criteria which allow us make the decision whether to split or not: Splitting should only take place if it holds that both (a) we are close to a stationary point of the FL objective

0‚â§‚Äñ‚àëi=1,..,mDi|Dc|‚Äã‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñ<Œµ1\displaystyle 0\leq\|\sum_{i=1,..,m}\frac{D_{i}}{|D_{c}|}\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta^{*})\|<\varepsilon_{1} (32)

and (b) the individual clients are far from a stationary point of their local empirical risk

maxi=1,..,m‚Å°‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñ>Œµ2>0\displaystyle\max_{i=1,..,m}\|\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta^{*})\|>\varepsilon_{2}>0 (33)

Figure 2 gives a visual illustration of this idea for a simple two dimensional problem. We will also experimentally verify the clustering criteria (32) and (33) in section VI-B.

In practice we have another viable option to distinguish the congruent from the incongruent case. As splitting will only be performed after Federated Learning has converged to a stationary point, we always have computed the conventional Federated Learning solution as part of Clustered Federated Learning. This means that if after splitting up the clients a degradation in model performance is observed, it is always possible to fall back to the Federated Learning solution. In this sense Clustered Federated Learning will always improve the Federated Learning performance (or perform equally well at worst).

III Clustered Federated Learning

Clustered Federated Learning recursively bi-partitions the client population in a top-down way: Starting from an initial set of clients c={1,..,m}c=\{1,..,m\} and a parameter initialization Œ∏0subscriptùúÉ0\theta_{0}, CFL performs Federated Learning according to Algorithm 2, in order to obtain a stationary solution Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} of the FL objective. After Federated Learning has converged, the stopping criterion

0‚â§maxi‚ààc‚Å°‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñ<Œµ20subscriptùëñùëênormsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëñsuperscriptùúÉsubscriptùúÄ2\displaystyle 0\leq\max_{i\in c}\|\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta^{*})\|<\varepsilon_{2} (34)

is evaluated. If criterion (34) is satisfied, we know that all clients are sufficiently close to a stationary solution of their local risk and consequently CFL terminates, returning the FL solution Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*}. If on the other hand, criterion (34) is violated, this means that the clients are incongruent and the server computes the pairwise cosine similarities Œ±ùõº\alpha between the clients‚Äô latest transmitted updates according to equation (LABEL:eq:cossim). Next, the server separates the clients into two clusters in such a way that the maximum similarity between clients from different clusters is minimized

c1,c2‚Üêarg‚Å°minc1‚à™c2=c‚Å°(maxi‚ààc1,j‚ààc2‚Å°Œ±i,j).‚Üêsubscriptùëê1subscriptùëê2subscriptsubscriptùëê1subscriptùëê2ùëêsubscriptformulae-sequenceùëñsubscriptùëê1ùëósubscriptùëê2subscriptùõºùëñùëó\displaystyle c_{1},c_{2}\leftarrow\arg\min_{c_{1}\cup c_{2}=c}(\max_{i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}}\alpha_{i,j}). (35)

This optimal bi-partitioning problem at the core of CFL can be solved in ùí™‚Äã(m3)ùí™superscriptùëö3\mathcal{O}(m^{3}) using Algorithm 1. Since in Federated Learning it is assumed that the server has far greater computational power than the clients, the overhead of clustering will typically be negligible.

As derived in section II, a correct bi-partitioning can always be ensured if it holds that

Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãn>Œ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãx.superscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë†ùëöùëéùë•\displaystyle\alpha_{intra}^{min}>\alpha_{cross}^{max}. (36)

While the optimal cross-cluster similarity Œ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãxsubscriptsuperscriptùõºùëöùëéùë•ùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë†\alpha^{max}_{cross} can be easily computed in practice, computation of the intra cluster similarity requires knowledge of the clustering structure and hence Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãnsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõ\alpha_{intra}^{min} can only be estimated using Theorem 1 according to

Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãnsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõ\displaystyle\alpha_{intra}^{min} ‚â•mini,jI‚Äã(i)=I‚Äã(j)‚àíŒ≥i‚ÄãŒ≥j+1‚àíŒ≥i2‚Äã1‚àíŒ≥j2absentsubscriptùêºùëñùêºùëóùëñùëósubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùõæùëó1superscriptsubscriptùõæùëñ21superscriptsubscriptùõæùëó2\displaystyle\geq\min_{\underset{I(i)=I(j)}{i,j}}-\gamma_{i}\gamma_{j}+\sqrt{1-\gamma_{i}^{2}}\sqrt{1-\gamma_{j}^{2}} (37)
‚â•1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥m‚Äãa‚Äãx2.absent12superscriptsubscriptùõæùëöùëéùë•2\displaystyle\geq 1-2\gamma_{max}^{2}. (38)

Consequently we know that the bi-partitioning will be correct if

Œ≥m‚Äãa‚Äãx<1‚àíŒ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãx2.subscriptùõæùëöùëéùë•1superscriptsubscriptùõºùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë†ùëöùëéùë•2\displaystyle\gamma_{max}<\sqrt{\frac{1-\alpha_{cross}^{max}}{2}}. (39)

independent of the number of data generating distributions kùëòk! This criterion allows us to reject bi-partitionings, based on our assumptions on the approximation noise Œ≥m‚Äãa‚Äãxsubscriptùõæùëöùëéùë•\gamma_{max} (which is an interpretable hyperparameter).

If criterion (39) is satisfied, CFL is recursively re-applied to each of the two separate groups starting from the stationary solution Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*}. Splitting recursively continues on until (after at most k‚àí1ùëò1k-1 recursions) none of the sub-clusters violate the stopping criterion anymore, at which point all groups of mutually congruent clients ùíû={c1,..,ck}\mathcal{C}=\{c_{1},..,c_{k}\} have been identified, and the Clustered Federated Learning problem characterized by Assumption 2 is solved. The entire recursive procedure is presented in Algorithm 3.

IV Related Work

Federated Learning [1][2][8][5][9][4] is currently the dominant framework for distributed training of machine learning models under communication- and privacy constraints. Federated Learning assumes the clients to be congruent, i.e. that one central model can fit all client‚Äôs distributions at the same time. Different authors have investigated the convergence properties of Federated Learning in congruent iid and non-iid scenarios: [10],[11],[12] and [13] perform an empirical investigation, [6], [14], [15] and [7] prove convergence guarantees. As argued in section I conventional Federated Learning is not able to deal with the challenges of incongruent data distributions. Other distributed training frameworks [16][17][18][19] are facing the same issues.

The natural framework for dealing with incongruent data is Multi-Task Learning [20][21][22]. An overview over recent techniques for multi-task learning in deep neural networks can be found in [23]. However all of these techniques are applied in a centralized setting in which all data resides at one location and the server has full control over and knowledge about the optimization process. Smith et al. [24] present MOCHA, which extends the multi-task learning approach to the Federated Learning setting, by explicitly modeling client similarity via a correlation matrix. However their method relies on alternating bi-convex optimization and is thus only applicable to convex objective functions and limited in it‚Äôs ability to scale to massive client populations. Corinzia et al. [25] model the connectivity structure between clients and server as a Bayesian network and perform variational inference during learning. Although their method can handle non-convex models, it is expensive to generalize to large federated networks as the client models are refined sequentially.

Finally, Ghosh et al. [26] propose a clustering approach, similar to the one presented in this paper. However their method differs from ours in the following key aspects: Most significantly they use l‚Äã2ùëô2l2-distance instead of cosine similarity to determine the distribution similarity of the clients. This approach has the severe limitation that it only works if the client‚Äôs risk functions are convex and the minima of different clusters are well separated. The l‚Äã2ùëô2l2-distance also is not able to distinguish congruent from incongruent settings. This means that the method will incorrectly split up clients in the conventional congruent non-iid setting described in [1]. Furthermore, their approach is not adaptive in the sense that the decision whether to cluster or not has to be made after the first communication round. In contrast, our method can be applied to arbitrary Federated Learning problems with non-convex objective functions. We also note that we have provided theoretical considerations that allow a systematic understanding of the novel CFL framework.

V Implementation Considerations

V-A Weight-Updates as generalized Gradients

Theorem 1 makes a statement about the cosine similarity between gradients of the empirical risk function. In Federated Learning however, due to constraints on both the memory of the client devices and their communication budged, instead commonly weight-updates as defined in (1) are computed and communicated. In order to deviate as little as possible from the classical Federated Learning algorithm it would hence be desirable to generalize result 1 to weight-updates. It is commonly conjectured (see e.g. [27]) that accumulated mini-batch gradients approximate the full-batch gradient of the objective function. Indeed, for a sufficiently smooth loss function and low learning rate, a weight update computed over one epoch approximates the direction of the true gradient since by Taylor approximation we have

‚àáŒ∏r‚Äã(Œ∏œÑ+Œ∑‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏œÑ‚àí1,DœÑ)subscript‚àáùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉùúèùúÇŒîsubscriptùúÉùúè1subscriptùê∑ùúè\displaystyle\nabla_{\theta}r(\theta_{\tau}+\eta\Delta\theta_{\tau-1},D_{\tau}) (40)
=‚àáŒ∏r‚Äã(Œ∏œÑ,DœÑ)+Œ∑‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏œÑ‚àí1‚Äã‚àáŒ∏2r‚Äã(Œ∏œÑ,DœÑ)+ùí™‚Äã(‚ÄñŒ∑‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏œÑ‚àí1‚Äñ2)absentsubscript‚àáùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉùúèsubscriptùê∑ùúèùúÇŒîsubscriptùúÉùúè1subscriptsuperscript‚àá2ùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉùúèsubscriptùê∑ùúèùí™superscriptnormùúÇŒîsubscriptùúÉùúè12\displaystyle=\nabla_{\theta}r(\theta_{\tau},D_{\tau})+\eta\Delta\theta_{\tau-1}\nabla^{2}_{\theta}r(\theta_{\tau},D_{\tau})+\mathcal{O}(\|\eta\Delta\theta_{\tau-1}\|^{2}) (41)
=‚àáŒ∏r‚Äã(Œ∏œÑ,DœÑ)+Rabsentsubscript‚àáùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉùúèsubscriptùê∑ùúèùëÖ\displaystyle=\nabla_{\theta}r(\theta_{\tau},D_{\tau})+R (42)

where RùëÖR can be bounded in norm. Hence, by recursive application of the above result it follows

Œî‚ÄãŒ∏=‚àëœÑ=1T‚àáŒ∏r‚Äã(Œ∏œÑ,DœÑ)‚âà‚àëœÑ=1T‚àáŒ∏r‚Äã(Œ∏1,DœÑ)=‚àáŒ∏r‚Äã(Œ∏1,D).ŒîùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùúè1ùëásubscript‚àáùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉùúèsubscriptùê∑ùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùúè1ùëásubscript‚àáùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉ1subscriptùê∑ùúèsubscript‚àáùúÉùëüsubscriptùúÉ1ùê∑\displaystyle\Delta\theta=\sum_{\tau=1}^{T}\nabla_{\theta}r(\theta_{\tau},D_{\tau})\approx\sum_{\tau=1}^{T}\nabla_{\theta}r(\theta_{1},D_{\tau})=\nabla_{\theta}r(\theta_{1},D). (43)

In the remainder of this work we will compute cosine similarities between weight-updates instead of gradients according to

Œ±i,j:=‚ü®Œî‚ÄãŒ∏i,Œî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚ü©‚ÄñŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i‚Äñ‚Äã‚ÄñŒî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚Äñ,i,j‚ààcformulae-sequenceassignsubscriptùõºùëñùëóŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñŒîsubscriptùúÉùëónormŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñnormŒîsubscriptùúÉùëóùëñùëóùëê\displaystyle\alpha_{i,j}:=\frac{\langle\Delta\theta_{i},\Delta\theta_{j}\rangle}{\|\Delta\theta_{i}\|\|\Delta\theta_{j}\|},i,j\in c (44)

Our experiments in section VI will demonstrate that computing cosine similarities based on weight-updates in practice surprisingly achieves even better separations than computing cosine similarities based on gradients.

V-B Preserving Privacy

Every machine learning model carries information about the data it has been trained on. For example the bias term in the last layer of a neural network will typically carry information about the label distribution of the training data. Different authors have demonstrated that information about a client‚Äôs input data ("xùë•x") can be inferred from the weight-updates it sends to the server via model inversion attacks [28][29][30][31][32]. In privacy sensitive situations it might be necessary to prevent this type of information leakage from clients to server with mechanisms like the ones presented in [3]. Luckily, Clustered Federated Learning can be easily augmented with an encryption mechanism that achieves this end. As both the cosine similarity between two clients‚Äô weight-updates and the norms of these updates are invariant to orthonormal transformations PùëÉP (such as permutation of the indices),

‚ü®Œî‚ÄãŒ∏i,Œî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚ü©‚ÄñŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i‚Äñ‚Äã‚ÄñŒî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚Äñ=‚ü®P‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i,P‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚ü©‚ÄñP‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i‚Äñ‚Äã‚ÄñP‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚ÄñŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñŒîsubscriptùúÉùëónormŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñnormŒîsubscriptùúÉùëóùëÉŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñùëÉŒîsubscriptùúÉùëónormùëÉŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñnormùëÉŒîsubscriptùúÉùëó\displaystyle\frac{\langle\Delta\theta_{i},\Delta\theta_{j}\rangle}{\|\Delta\theta_{i}\|\|\Delta\theta_{j}\|}=\frac{\langle P\Delta\theta_{i},P\Delta\theta_{j}\rangle}{\|P\Delta\theta_{i}\|\|P\Delta\theta_{j}\|} (45)

a simple remedy is for all clients to apply such a transformation operator to their updates before communicating them to the server. After the server has averaged the updates from all clients and broadcasted the average back to the clients they simply apply the inverse operation

Œî‚ÄãŒ∏=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i=P‚àí1‚Äã(1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nP‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i)ŒîùúÉ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñsuperscriptùëÉ11ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùëÉŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñ\displaystyle\Delta\theta=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta\theta_{i}=P^{-1}(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}P\Delta\theta_{i}) (46)

and the Federated Learning protocol can resume unchanged. Other multi-task learning approaches require direct access to the client‚Äôs data and hence can not be used together with encryption, which represents a distinct advantage for CFL in privacy sensitive situations.

V-C Varying Client Populations and Parameter Trees

Up until now we always made the assumption that all clients participate from the beginning of training. Clustered Federated Learning however is flexible enough to handle client populations that vary over time.

In order to incorporate this functionality, the server, while running CFL, needs to build a parameter tree T=(V,E)ùëáùëâùê∏T=(V,E) with the following properties:

    are cached

An exemplary parameter tree is shown in Figure 4. When a new client joins the training it can get assigned to a leaf cluster by iteratively traversing the parameter tree from the root to a leaf, always moving to the branch which contains the more similar client updates according to Algorithm 4.

Another feature of building a parameter tree is that it allows the server to provide every client with multiple models at varying specificity. On the path from root to leaf, the models get more specialized with the most general model being the FL model at the root. Depending on application and context, a CFL client could switch between models of different generality. Furthermore a parameter tree allows us to ensemble multiple models of different specificity together. We believe that investigations along those lines are a promising direction of future research.

Putting all pieces from the previous sections together, we arrive at a protocol for general privacy-preserving CFL which is described in Algorithm 5

VI Experiments

VI-A Practical Considerations

In section II we showed that the cosine similarity criterion does distinguish different incongruent clients under three conditions: (a) Federated Learning has converged to a stationary point Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*}, (b) Every client holds enough data s.t. the empirical risk approximates the true risk, (c) cosine similarity is computed between the full gradients of the empirical risk. In this section we will demonstrate that in practical problems none of these conditions have to be fully satisfied. Instead, we will find that CFL is able to correctly infer the clustering structure even if clients only hold small datasets and are trained to an approximately stationary solution of the Federated Learning objective. Furthermore we will see that cosine similarity can be computed between weight-updates instead of full gradients, which even improves performance.

In the experiments of this section we consider the following Federated Learning setup: All experiments are performed on either the MNIST [33] or CIFAR-10 [34] dataset using m=20ùëö20m=20 clients, each of which belonging to one of k=4ùëò4k=4 clusters. Every client is assigned an equally sized random subset of the total training data. To simulate an incongruent clustering structure, every clients‚Äô data is then modified by randomly swapping out two labels, depending on which cluster a client belongs to. For example, in all clients belonging to the first cluster, data points labeled as "1" could be relabeled as "7" and vice versa, in all clients belonging to the second cluster "3" and "5" could be switched out in the same way, and so on. This relabeling ensures that both œÜ‚Äã(x)ùúëùë•\varphi(x) and œÜ‚Äã(y)ùúëùë¶\varphi(y) are approximately the same across all clients, but the conditionals œÜ‚Äã(y|x)ùúëconditionalùë¶ùë•\varphi(y|x) diverge between different clusters. We will refer to this as "label-swap augmentation" in the following. In all experiments we train multi-layer convolutional neural networks and adopt a standard Federated Learning strategy with 3 local epochs of training. We report the separation gap (Definition 2)

g‚Äã(Œ±):=Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãn‚àíŒ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãxassignùëîùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë†ùëöùëéùë•\displaystyle g(\alpha):=\alpha_{intra}^{min}-\alpha_{cross}^{max} (48)

which according to Corollary 1 tells us whether CFL will correctly bi-partition the clients:

g‚Äã(Œ±)>0‚áî"Correct Clustering"‚áîùëîùõº0"Correct Clustering"\displaystyle g(\alpha)>0\Leftrightarrow\text{"Correct Clustering"} (49)

Number of Data points: We start out by investigating the effects of data set size on the cosine similarity. We randomly subsample from each client‚Äôs training data to vary the number of data points on every client between 10 and 200 for MNIST and 100 and 2400 for CIFAR. For every different local data set size we run Federated Learning for 50 communication rounds, after which training progress has come mostly to halt and we can expect to be close to a stationary point. After round 50, we compute the pairwise cosine similarities between the weight-updates and the separation gap g‚Äã(Œ±)ùëîùõºg(\alpha). The results are shown in Figure 5. As expected, g‚Äã(Œ±)ùëîùõºg(\alpha) grows monotonically with increasing data set size. On the MNIST problem as little as 20 data points on every client are sufficient to achieve correct bi-partitioning in the sense of Definition 1. On the more difficult CIFAR problem a higher number of around 500 data points is necessary to achieve correct bi-partitioning.

Proximity to Stationary Solution: Next, we investigate the importance of proximity to a stationary point Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} for the clustering. Under the same setting as in the previous experiment we reduce the number of data points on every client to 100 for MNIST and to 1500 for CIFAR and compute the pairwise cosine similarities and the separation gap after each of the first 50 communication rounds. The results are shown in Figure 6. Again, we see that the separation quality monotonically increases with the number of communication rounds. On MNIST and CIFAR as little as 10 communication rounds are necessary to obtain a correct clustering.

Weight-Updates instead of Gradients: In both the above experiments we computed the cosine similarities Œ±ùõº\alpha based on either the full gradients

Œ±i,j=‚ü®‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏),‚àáŒ∏rj‚Äã(Œ∏)‚ü©‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äñ‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏rj‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äñ¬†("Gradient")subscriptùõºùëñùëósubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëñùúÉsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëóùúÉnormsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëñùúÉnormsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëóùúÉ¬†("Gradient")\displaystyle\alpha_{i,j}=\frac{\langle\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta),\nabla_{\theta}r_{j}(\theta)\rangle}{\|\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta)\|\|\nabla_{\theta}r_{j}(\theta)\|}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \text{ ("Gradient") } (50)

or Federated weight-updates

Œ±i,j=‚ü®Œî‚ÄãŒ∏i,Œî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚ü©‚ÄñŒî‚ÄãŒ∏i‚Äñ‚Äã‚ÄñŒî‚ÄãŒ∏j‚Äñ¬†("Weight-Update")subscriptùõºùëñùëóŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñŒîsubscriptùúÉùëónormŒîsubscriptùúÉùëñnormŒîsubscriptùúÉùëó¬†("Weight-Update")\displaystyle\alpha_{i,j}=\frac{\langle\Delta\theta_{i},\Delta\theta_{j}\rangle}{\|\Delta\theta_{i}\|\|\Delta\theta_{j}\|}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \text{ ("Weight-Update") } (51)

over 3 epochs. Interestingly, weight-updates seem to provide even better separation g‚Äã(Œ±)ùëîùõºg(\alpha) with fewer data points and at a greater distance to a stationary solution. This comes in very handy as it allows us to leave the Federated Learning communication protocol unchanged. In all following experiments we will compute cosine similarities based on weight-updates instead of gradients.

VI-B Distinguishing Congruent and Incongruent Clients

In this subsection, we experimentally verify the validity of the clustering criteria (32) and (33) in a Federated Learning experiment on MNIST with two clients holding data from incongruent and congruent distributions. In the congruent case client one holds all training digits "0" to "4" and client two holds all training digits "5" to "9". In the incongruent case, both clients hold a random subset of the training data, but the distributions are modified according to the "label swap" rule described above. Figure 7 shows the development of the average update norm (equation (32)) and the maximum client norm (equation (33)) over the course of 1000 communication rounds. As predicted by the theory, in the congruent case the average client norm converges to zero, while in the incongruent case it stagnates and even increases over time. In both cases the server norm tends to zero, indicating convergence to a stationary point (see Figure 7).

VI-C Clustered Federated Learning

In this section, we apply CFL as described in Algorithm 5 to different Federated Learning setups, which are inspired by our motivating examples in the introduction. In all experiments, the clients perform 3 epochs of local training at a batch-size of 100 in every communication round.

Label permutation on Cifar-10: We split the CIFAR-10 training data randomly and evenly among m=20ùëö20m=20 clients, which we group into k=4ùëò4k=4 different clusters. All clients belonging to the same cluster apply the same random permutation Pc‚Äã(i)subscriptùëÉùëêùëñP_{c(i)} to their labels such that their modified training and test data is given by

Di^={(x,Pc‚Äã(i)‚Äã(y))|(x,y)‚ààDi}^subscriptùê∑ùëñconditional-setùë•subscriptùëÉùëêùëñùë¶ùë•ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùëñ\displaystyle\hat{D_{i}}=\{(x,P_{c(i)}(y))|(x,y)\in D_{i}\} (52)

respective

Dit‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äãt^={(x,Pc‚Äã(i)‚Äã(y))|(x,y)‚ààDt‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äãt}.^subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùë°ùëíùë†ùë°ùëñconditional-setùë•subscriptùëÉùëêùëñùë¶ùë•ùë¶superscriptùê∑ùë°ùëíùë†ùë°\displaystyle\hat{D^{test}_{i}}=\{(x,P_{c(i)}(y))|(x,y)\in D^{test}\}. (53)

The clients then jointly train a 5-layer convolutional neural network on the modified data using CFL with 3 epochs of local training at a batch-size of 100. Figure 8 (top) shows the joint training progression: In the first 50 communication rounds, all clients train one single model together, following the conventional Federated Learning protocol. After these initial 50 rounds, training has converged to a stationary point of the Federated Learning objective and the client test accuracies stagnate at around 20%. Conventional Federated Learning would be finalized at this point. At the same time, we observe (Figure 8, bottom) that a distinct gap g‚Äã(Œ±)=Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãn‚àíŒ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãxùëîùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë†ùëöùëéùë•g(\alpha)=\alpha_{intra}^{min}-\alpha_{cross}^{max} has developed ( ), indicating an underlying clustering structure. In communication round 50 the client population is therefore split up for the first time, which leads to an immediate 25% increase in validation accuracy for all clients belonging to the "purple" cluster which was separated out . Splitting is repeated in communication rounds 100 and 150 until all clusters have been separated and g‚Äã(Œ±)ùëîùõºg(\alpha) has dropped to below zero in all clusters ( ), which indicates that clustering is finalized. At this point the accuracy of all clients has more than doubled the one achieved by the Federated Learning solution and is now at close to 60% . This underlines, that after standard FL, our novel CFL can detect, the necessity for subsequent splitting and clustering which enables arriving at significantly higher performance. In addition, the cluster structure found can potentially be illuminating as it provides interesting insight about the composition of the complex underlying data distribution.

Language Modeling on Ag-News: The Ag-News corpus is a collection of 120000 news articles belonging to one of the four topics ‚ÄôWorld‚Äô, ‚ÄôSports‚Äô, ‚ÄôBusiness‚Äô and ‚ÄôSci/Tech‚Äô. We split the corpus into 20 different sub-corpora of the same size, with every sub-corpus containing only articles from one topic and assign every corpus to one client. Consequently the clients form four clusters based on what type of articles they hold. Every Client trains a two-layer LSTM network to predict the next word on it‚Äôs local corpus of articles. Figure 9 shows 100 communication rounds of multi-stage CFL applied to this distributed learning problem. As we can see, Federated Learning again converges to a stationary solution after around 30 communication rounds. At this solution all clients achieve a perplexity of around 43 on their local test set. After the client population has been split up in communication rounds 30, 60 and 90, the four true underlying clusters are discovered. After the 100th communication round the perplexity of all clients has dropped to less than 36. The Federated Learning solution, trained over the same amount of communication rounds, still stagnates at an average perplexity of 42.

VII Conclusion

In this paper we presented Clustered Federated Learning, a framework for Federated Multi-Task Learning that can improve any existing Federated Learning Framework by enabling the participating clients to learn more specialized models. Clustered Federated Learning makes use of our theoretical finding, that (at any stationary solution of the Federated Learning objective) the cosine similarity between the weight-updates of different clients is highly indicative of the similarity of their data distributions. This crucial insight allows us to provide strong mathematic guarantees on the clustering quality under mild assumptions on the clients and their data, even for arbitrary non-convex objectives.

We demonstrated that CFL can be implemented in a privacy preserving way and without having to modify the FL communication protocol. Moreover, CFL is able to distinguish situations in which a single model can be learned from the clients‚Äô data from those in which this is not possible and only separates clients in the latter case.

Our experiments on convolutional and recurrent deep neural networks show that CFL can achieve drastic improvements over the Federated Learning baseline in terms of classification accuracy / perplexity in situations where the clients‚Äô data exhibits a clustering structure.

In future work we plan to further investigate the utility of weight-updates for distribution similarity estimation. Another interesting direction of further research is whether our results will also generalize to compressed weight-updates [35][36][37] or compact parameter representations [38].

VIII-A Proving the Separation Theorem

The Separation Theorem 1 makes a statement about the cosine similarities between the gradients of the empirical risk functions ‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)subscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëñsuperscriptùúÉ\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta^{*}) and ‚àáŒ∏rj‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)subscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëósuperscriptùúÉ\nabla_{\theta}r_{j}(\theta^{*}), which are noisy approximations of the true risk gradients ‚àáŒ∏RI‚Äã(i)‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)subscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëÖùêºùëñsuperscriptùúÉ\nabla_{\theta}R_{I(i)}(\theta^{*}), respective ‚àáŒ∏RI‚Äã(j)‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)subscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëÖùêºùëósuperscriptùúÉ\nabla_{\theta}R_{I(j)}(\theta^{*}). and

the clustering will always be correct.

The proof of Theorem 1 can be organized into three separate steps:

  • ‚Ä¢

    In Lemma 2, we bound the cosine similarity between two noisy approximations of the same vector Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãnsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõ\alpha_{intra}^{min} from below

  • ‚Ä¢

    In Lemma 3, we bound the cosine similarity between two noisy approximations of two different vectors from above

  • ‚Ä¢

    In Lemma 4, we show that every set of vectors that sums to zero can be separated into two groups such that the cosine similarity between any two vectors from separate groups can be bounded from above

  • ‚Ä¢

    Lemma 3 and 4 together will allow us to bound the cross cluster similarity Œ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãxsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë†ùëöùëéùë•\alpha_{cross}^{max} from above

Lemma 2.

Let v,X,Y‚àà‚Ñùdùë£ùëãùëåsuperscript‚Ñùùëëv,X,Y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with ‚ÄñX‚Äñ<‚Äñv‚Äñnormùëãnormùë£\|X\|<\|v\| and ‚ÄñY‚Äñ<‚Äñv‚Äñnormùëånormùë£\|Y\|<\|v\| then

Œ±‚Äã(v+X,v+Y)‚â•‚àí‚ÄñX‚Äñ‚Äã‚ÄñY‚Äñ‚Äñv‚Äñ2+1‚àí‚ÄñX‚Äñ2‚Äñv‚Äñ2‚Äã1‚àí‚ÄñY‚Äñ2‚Äñv‚Äñ2.ùõºùë£ùëãùë£ùëånormùëãnormùëåsuperscriptnormùë£21superscriptnormùëã2superscriptnormùë£21superscriptnormùëå2superscriptnormùë£2\displaystyle\alpha(v+X,v+Y)\geq-\frac{\|X\|\|Y\|}{\|v\|^{2}}+\sqrt{1-\frac{\|X\|^{2}}{\|v\|^{2}}}\sqrt{1-\frac{\|Y\|^{2}}{\|v\|^{2}}}. (58)
Proof.

Œ±‚Äã(v+X,v+Y)=cos‚Å°(‚à¢‚Äã(v+X,v+Y))ùõºùë£ùëãùë£ùëå‚à¢ùë£ùëãùë£ùëå\displaystyle\alpha(v+X,v+Y)=\cos(\sphericalangle(v+X,v+Y)) (59)

and cos\cos is monotonically decreasing on [0,œÄ]0ùúã[0,\pi] such XùëãX and YùëåY will minimize the cosine similarity Œ±ùõº\alpha. As ‚ÄñX‚Äñ<‚Äñv‚Äñnormùëãnormùë£\|X\|<\|v\| and ‚ÄñY‚Äñ<‚Äñv‚Äñnormùëånormùë£\|Y\|<\|v\| the angle will be maximized if and only if vùë£v, XùëãX and YùëåY share a common 2-dimensional hyperplane, XùëãX is perpendicular to v+Xùë£ùëãv+X and YùëåY is perpendicular to v+Yùë£ùëåv+Y and XùëãX and YùëåY point into opposite directions (Figure 11). sin‚Å°(‚à¢‚Äã(v,v+X))=‚ÄñX‚Äñ‚Äñv‚Äñ‚à¢ùë£ùë£ùëãnormùëãnormùë£\displaystyle\sin(\sphericalangle(v,v+X))=\frac{\|X\|}{\|v\|} (60)

and

and hence

cos‚Å°(‚à¢‚Äã(v+X,v+Y))‚à¢ùë£ùëãùë£ùëå\displaystyle\cos(\sphericalangle(v+X,v+Y)) =cos‚Å°(‚à¢‚Äã(v+X)+‚à¢‚Äã(v+Y))absent‚à¢ùë£ùëã‚à¢ùë£ùëå\displaystyle=\cos(\sphericalangle(v+X)+\sphericalangle(v+Y)) (62)

Lemma 3.

‚à¢(v+X,w+Y)‚â•max(0,\displaystyle\sphericalangle(v+X,w+Y)\geq\max(0, cos‚àí1‚Å°(‚ü®v,w‚ü©‚Äñv‚Äñ‚Äã‚Äñw‚Äñ)superscript1ùë£ùë§normùë£normùë§\displaystyle\cos^{-1}(\frac{\langle v,w\rangle}{\|v\|\|w\|}) (74)

Since

the result follows after re-arranging terms. ‚àé

Lemma 4.

Let v1,..,vk‚àà‚Ñùdv_{1},..,v_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, d‚â•2ùëë2d\geq 2, Œ≥1,..,Œ≥k‚àà‚Ñù>0\gamma_{1},..,\gamma_{k}\in\mathbb{R}_{>0} and

‚àëi=1kŒ≥i‚Äãvi=0‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùë£ùëñ0superscript‚Ñùùëë\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{k}\gamma_{i}v_{i}=0\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (81)

then there exists a bi-partitioning of the vectors c1‚à™c2={1,..,k}c_{1}\cup c_{2}=\{1,..,k\} such that

maxi‚ààc1,j‚ààc2‚Å°Œ±‚Äã(vi,vj)‚â§cos‚Å°(œÄk‚àí1)subscriptformulae-sequenceùëñsubscriptùëê1ùëósubscriptùëê2ùõºsubscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëóùúãùëò1\displaystyle\max_{i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}}\alpha(v_{i},v_{j})\leq\cos(\frac{\pi}{k-1}) (82)
Proof.

Lemma 4 can be equivalently stated as follows:

Let v1,..,vk‚àà‚Ñùdv_{1},..,v_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, d‚â•2ùëë2d\geq 2, Œ≥1,..,Œ≥k‚àà‚Ñù>0\gamma_{1},..,\gamma_{k}\in\mathbb{R}_{>0} and

‚àëi=1kŒ≥i‚Äãvi=0‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùë£ùëñ0superscript‚Ñùùëë\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{k}\gamma_{i}v_{i}=0\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (83)

then there exists a bi-partitioning of the vectors c1‚à™c2={1,..,k}c_{1}\cup c_{2}=\{1,..,k\} such that

mini‚ààc1,j‚ààc2‚Å°‚à¢‚Äã(vi,vj)‚â•œÄk‚àí1subscriptformulae-sequenceùëñsubscriptùëê1ùëósubscriptùëê2‚à¢subscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëóùúãùëò1\displaystyle\min_{i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}}\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{j})\geq\frac{\pi}{k-1} (84)

As the angle between two vectors is invariant under multiplication with positive scalars Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0 we can assume w.l.o.g that Œ≥i=1subscriptùõæùëñ1\gamma_{i}=1 i=1,..,ki=1,..,k.

Let us first consider the case where d=2ùëë2d=2. Let e1‚àà‚Ñù2subscriptùëí1superscript‚Ñù2e_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{2} be the first standard basis vector and assume w.l.o.g that the vectors v1,..,vkv_{1},..,v_{k} are sorted w.r.t. their angular distance to e1subscriptùëí1e_{1} (they are arranged circular as shows in Figure 12). As all vectors lie in the 2d plane, we know that the sum of the angles between all neighboring vectors has to be equal to 2‚ÄãœÄ2ùúã2\pi.

‚àëi=1k‚à¢‚Äã(vi,v(i+1)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk)=2‚ÄãœÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëò‚à¢subscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëñ1¬†mod¬†ùëò2ùúã\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{k}\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{(i+1)\text{ mod }k})=2\pi (85)

Now let

i1‚àó=arg‚Å°maxi‚àà{1,..,k}‚Å°‚à¢‚Äã(vi,v(i+1)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk)\displaystyle i_{1}^{*}=\arg\max_{i\in\{1,..,k\}}\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{(i+1)\text{ mod }k}) (86)

and

i2‚àó=arg‚Å°maxi‚àà{1,..,k}‚àñi1‚àó‚Å°‚à¢‚Äã(vi,v(i+1)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk)\displaystyle i_{2}^{*}=\arg\max_{i\in\{1,..,k\}\setminus i_{1}^{*}}\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{(i+1)\text{ mod }k}) (87)

be the indices of the largest and second largest angles between neighboring vectors and define the following clusters:

c1subscriptùëê1\displaystyle c_{1} ={i‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk|i1‚àó<i‚â§i2‚àó+k‚Äã[i2‚àó<i1‚àó]}absentconditional-setùëñ¬†mod¬†ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ2ùëòdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1\displaystyle=\{i\text{ mod }k|i_{1}^{*}<i\leq i_{2}^{*}+k[i_{2}^{*}<i_{1}^{*}]\} (88)
c2subscriptùëê2\displaystyle c_{2} ={i¬†mod¬†k|i2‚àó<i‚â§i1‚àó+k[i2‚àó>i1‚àó]}}\displaystyle=\{i\text{ mod }k|i_{2}^{*}<i\leq i_{1}^{*}+k[i_{2}^{*}>i_{1}^{*}]\}\} (89)

where [x]=1delimited-[]ùë•1[x]=1 if xùë•x is true and [x]=0delimited-[]ùë•0[x]=0 is xùë•x is false. Then by construction the second largest angle ‚à¢‚Äã(vi2‚àó,v(i2‚àó+1)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk)‚à¢subscriptùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëñ2subscriptùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëñ21¬†mod¬†ùëò\sphericalangle(v_{i^{*}_{2}},v_{(i^{*}_{2}+1)\text{ mod }k}) minimizes the angle between any two vectors from the two different clusters c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}, c2subscriptùëê2c_{2} (see Figure 12 for an illustration):

mini‚ààc1,j‚ààc2‚Å°‚à¢‚Äã(vi,vj)=‚à¢‚Äã(vi2‚àó,v(i2‚àó+1)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk)subscriptformulae-sequenceùëñsubscriptùëê1ùëósubscriptùëê2‚à¢subscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëó‚à¢subscriptùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëñ2subscriptùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëñ21¬†mod¬†ùëò\displaystyle\min_{i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}}\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{j})=\sphericalangle(v_{i^{*}_{2}},v_{(i^{*}_{2}+1)\text{ mod }k}) (90)

Hence in d=2ùëë2d=2 we can always find a partitioning c1,c2subscriptùëê1subscriptùëê2c_{1},c_{2} s.t. the minimum angle between any two vectors from different clusters is greater or equal to the 2nd largest angle between neighboring vectors. This means the worst case configuration of vectors is one where the 2nd largest angle between neighboring vectors is minimized. As the sum of all kùëòk angles between neighboring vectors is constant according to (85), this is exactly the case when the largest angle between neighboring vectors is maximized and all other k‚àí1ùëò1k-1 angles are equal.

Assume now that the angle between two neighboring vectors is greater than œÄùúã\pi. That would mean that there exists a separating line lùëôl which passes through the origin and all vectors v1,..,vkv_{1},..,v_{k} lie on one side of that line. This however is impossible since ‚àël=1kvl=0superscriptsubscriptùëô1ùëòsubscriptùë£ùëô0\sum_{l=1}^{k}v_{l}=0. This means that the largest angle between neighboring vectors can not be greater than œÄùúã\pi. Hence in the worst-case scenario

‚à¢‚Äã(vi2‚àó,v(i2‚àó+1)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äãk)‚â•2‚ÄãœÄ‚àíœÄk‚àí1=œÄk‚àí1.‚à¢subscriptùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëñ2subscriptùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëñ21¬†mod¬†ùëò2ùúãùúãùëò1ùúãùëò1\displaystyle\sphericalangle(v_{i^{*}_{2}},v_{(i^{*}_{2}+1)\text{ mod }k})\geq\frac{2\pi-\pi}{k-1}=\frac{\pi}{k-1}. (91)

This concludes the proof for d=2ùëë2d=2.

Now consider he case where d>2ùëë2d>2. Let c1,c2subscriptùëê1subscriptùëê2c_{1},c_{2} be a clustering which maximizes the minimum angular distance between any two clients from different clusters. Let

i‚àó,j‚àó=arg‚Å°mini‚ààc1,j‚ààc2‚Å°‚à¢‚Äã(vi,vj)superscriptùëñsuperscriptùëósubscriptformulae-sequenceùëñsubscriptùëê1ùëósubscriptùëê2‚à¢subscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëó\displaystyle i^{*},j^{*}=\arg\min_{i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}}\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{j}) (92)

then vi‚àósubscriptùë£superscriptùëñv_{i^{*}} and vj‚àósubscriptùë£superscriptùëóv_{j^{*}} are the two vectors with minimal angular distance. Let A=[vi‚àó,vj‚àó]‚àà‚Ñùd,2ùê¥subscriptùë£superscriptùëñsubscriptùë£superscriptùëósuperscript‚Ñùùëë2A=[v_{i^{*}},v_{j^{*}}]\in\mathbb{R}^{d,2} and consider now the projection matrix

P=A‚Äã(AT‚ÄãA)‚àí1‚ÄãATùëÉùê¥superscriptsuperscriptùê¥ùëáùê¥1superscriptùê¥ùëá\displaystyle P=A(A^{T}A)^{-1}A^{T} (93)

which projects all d-dimensional vectors onto the plane spanned by vi‚àósubscriptùë£superscriptùëñv_{i^{*}} and vj‚àósubscriptùë£superscriptùëóv_{j^{*}}. Then be linearity of the projection we have

0=P‚Äã0=P‚Äã(‚àëi=1kvi)=‚àëi=1kP‚Äã(vi)0ùëÉ0ùëÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòsubscriptùë£ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòùëÉsubscriptùë£ùëñ\displaystyle 0=P0=P(\sum_{i=1}^{k}v_{i})=\sum_{i=1}^{k}P(v_{i}) (94)

Hence the projected vectors also satisfy the condition of the Lemma. As

‚à¢‚Äã(P‚Äãvi‚àó,P‚Äãvj‚àó)=‚à¢‚Äã(vi‚àó,vj‚àó)‚à¢ùëÉsubscriptùë£superscriptùëñùëÉsubscriptùë£superscriptùëó‚à¢subscriptùë£superscriptùëñsubscriptùë£superscriptùëó\displaystyle\sphericalangle(Pv_{i^{*}},Pv_{j^{*}})=\sphericalangle(v_{i^{*}},v_{j^{*}}) (95)

and

‚à¢‚Äã(P‚Äãvi,P‚Äãvj)‚â•‚à¢‚Äã(vi,vj)‚à¢ùëÉsubscriptùë£ùëñùëÉsubscriptùë£ùëó‚à¢subscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëó\displaystyle\sphericalangle(Pv_{i},Pv_{j})\geq\sphericalangle(v_{i},v_{j}) (96)

for all i,j‚àâ{i‚àó,j‚àó}ùëñùëósuperscriptùëñsuperscriptùëói,j\notin\{i^{*},j^{*}\} the clustering c1,c2subscriptùëê1subscriptùëê2c_{1},c_{2} is still optimal after projecting and we have found a 2d configuration of vectors satisfying the assumptions of Lemma 4 with the same minimal cross-cluster angle. In other words, we have reduced the d>2ùëë2d>2 case to the d=2ùëë2d=2 case, for which we have already proven the result. This concludes the proof.

Theorem 5 (Separation Theorem).

Let D1,..,DmD_{1},..,D_{m} be the local training data of mùëöm different clients, each dataset sampled from one of kùëòk different data generating distributions œÜ1,..,œÜk\varphi_{1},..,\varphi_{k}, such that Di‚àºœÜI‚Äã(i)‚Äã(x,y)similar-tosubscriptùê∑ùëñsubscriptùúëùêºùëñùë•ùë¶D_{i}\sim\varphi_{I(i)}(x,y). Let the empirical risk on every client approximate the true risk at every stationary solution of the Federated Learning objective Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} s.t.

‚Äñ‚àáRI‚Äã(i)‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñ>‚Äñ‚àáRI‚Äã(i)‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚àí‚àári‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñnorm‚àásubscriptùëÖùêºùëñsuperscriptùúÉnorm‚àásubscriptùëÖùêºùëñsuperscriptùúÉ‚àásubscriptùëüùëñsuperscriptùúÉ\displaystyle\|\nabla R_{I(i)}(\theta^{*})\|>\|\nabla R_{I(i)}(\theta^{*})-\nabla r_{i}(\theta^{*})\| (97)

and define

Œ≥i:=‚Äñ‚àáRI‚Äã(i)‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚àí‚àári‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñ‚Äñ‚àáRI‚Äã(i)‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)‚Äñ‚àà[0,1)assignsubscriptùõæùëñnorm‚àásubscriptùëÖùêºùëñsuperscriptùúÉ‚àásubscriptùëüùëñsuperscriptùúÉnorm‚àásubscriptùëÖùêºùëñsuperscriptùúÉ01\displaystyle\gamma_{i}:=\frac{\|\nabla R_{I(i)}(\theta^{*})-\nabla r_{i}(\theta^{*})\|}{\|\nabla R_{I(i)}(\theta^{*})\|}\in[0,1) (98)

Then there exists a bi-partitioning c1‚àó‚à™c2‚àó={1,..,m}c_{1}^{*}\cup c_{2}^{*}=\{1,..,m\} of the client population such that that the maximum similarity between the updates from any two clients from different clusters can be bounded from above according to

Œ±c‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äãsm‚Äãa‚Äãx:=minc1‚à™c2={1,..,m}‚Å°maxi‚ààc1,j‚ààc2‚Å°Œ±‚Äã(‚àári‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó),‚àárj‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó))\displaystyle\alpha_{cross}^{max}:=\min_{c_{1}\cup c_{2}=\{1,..,m\}}\max_{i\in c_{1},j\in c_{2}}\alpha(\nabla r_{i}(\theta^{*}),\nabla r_{j}(\theta^{*})) (99)
=maxi‚ààc1‚àó,j‚ààc2‚àó‚Å°Œ±‚Äã(‚àári‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó),‚àárj‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó))absentsubscriptformulae-sequenceùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëê2ùõº‚àásubscriptùëüùëñsuperscriptùúÉ‚àásubscriptùëüùëósuperscriptùúÉ\displaystyle=\max_{i\in c_{1}^{*},j\in c_{2}^{*}}\alpha(\nabla r_{i}(\theta^{*}),\nabla r_{j}(\theta^{*})) (100)
‚â§{cos‚Å°(œÄk‚àí1)‚ÄãHi,j+sin‚Å°(œÄk‚àí1)‚Äã1‚àíHi,j2¬†if¬†‚ÄãH‚â•cos‚Å°(œÄk‚àí1)1¬†elseabsentcasesùúãùëò1subscriptùêªùëñùëóùúãùëò11superscriptsubscriptùêªùëñùëó2¬†if¬†ùêªùúãùëò11¬†else\displaystyle\leq\begin{cases}\cos(\frac{\pi}{k-1})H_{i,j}+\sin(\frac{\pi}{k-1})\sqrt{1-H_{i,j}^{2}}&\text{ if }H\geq\cos(\frac{\pi}{k-1})\\ 1&\text{ else }\end{cases} (101)

with

At the same time the similarity between updates from clients which share the same data generating distribution can be bounded from below by

Œ±i‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äãam‚Äãi‚Äãn:=mini,jI‚Äã(i)=I‚Äã(j)‚Å°Œ±‚Äã(‚àáŒ∏ri‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó),‚àáŒ∏rj‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó))‚â•mini,jI‚Äã(i)=I‚Äã(j)‚Å°Hi,j.assignsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùëõùë°ùëüùëéùëöùëñùëõsubscriptùêºùëñùêºùëóùëñùëóùõºsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëñsuperscriptùúÉsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëüùëósuperscriptùúÉsubscriptùêºùëñùêºùëóùëñùëósubscriptùêªùëñùëó\displaystyle\alpha_{intra}^{min}:=\min_{\underset{I(i)=I(j)}{i,j}}\alpha(\nabla_{\theta}r_{i}(\theta^{*}),\nabla_{\theta}r_{j}(\theta^{*}))\geq\min_{\underset{I(i)=I(j)}{i,j}}H_{i,j}. (103)
Proof.

For the first result, we know that in every stationary solution of the Federated Learning objective Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùúÉ\theta^{*} it holds

‚àël=1kŒ≥i‚Äã‚àáŒ∏Rl‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)=0superscriptsubscriptùëô1ùëòsubscriptùõæùëñsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëÖùëôsuperscriptùúÉ0\displaystyle\sum_{l=1}^{k}\gamma_{i}\nabla_{\theta}R_{l}(\theta^{*})=0 (104)

and hence by Lemma 4 there exists a bi-partitioning c^1‚à™c^2={1,..,k}\hat{c}_{1}\cup\hat{c}_{2}=\{1,..,k\} such that

maxl‚ààc^1,j‚ààc^2‚Å°Œ±‚Äã(‚àáŒ∏Rl‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó),‚àáŒ∏Rj‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó))‚â§cos‚Å°(œÄk‚àí1)subscriptformulae-sequenceùëôsubscript^ùëê1ùëósubscript^ùëê2ùõºsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëÖùëôsuperscriptùúÉsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëÖùëósuperscriptùúÉùúãùëò1\displaystyle\max_{l\in\hat{c}_{1},j\in\hat{c}_{2}}\alpha(\nabla_{\theta}R_{l}(\theta^{*}),\nabla_{\theta}R_{j}(\theta^{*}))\leq\cos(\frac{\pi}{k-1}) (105)

Let

c1={i|I(i)‚ààc^1,i=1,..,m}\displaystyle c_{1}=\{i|I(i)\in\hat{c}_{1},i=1,..,m\} (106)

and
